main_text: I have been working at Apple
pros: I love working from home. My managers have always focused on helping me improve and move up in my career. They are so supportive and I feel like they really have my back. I feel like the training is adequate and I am prepared for calls when I get to the phones. I love my opportunity for advancement and have a lot of different avenues I can take within the company.
cons: Work/life balance is pretty bad. They do offer different schedule choices but I always have to either work weekends or a super late shift and I don’t get to spend time with my family. Every time my new schedule releases, I always refresh my resume thinking I’m going to find another place to work that has more reliable schedule but I can’t ever beat the pay that Apple offers so I’m just forever stuck with a terrible schedule that changes every 4 months. If Apple could figure out how to make the scheduling better for At-Home advisors, it would literally be the perfect place to work.
advice_management: Implement the “Follow the Sun” scheduling that so many people want. It fixes the scheduling problem all together.

main_text: I have been working at Apple full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Apple pays their workers competitively and have lots of amazing benefits.
They offer fitness reimbursement up to 300 for full time employees, 150 for part time.  The give 5,200 for tuition reimbursement. The health, dental and vision care is amazing. Also a 100 stipend to take the train or use for uber pools. You are also surrounded by creatives all day, people from all walks of life that you can network  with. Repairing is challenging but with the right time member its a fun work environment .
cons:
On going training needs to be mandatory. there's so many products always releasing but not enough alignment or hands on training to truly understand how to troubleshoot and resolve issue.

Dealing with ambiguity is sometime overwhelming. There is so much of it and management is no help. Depending on who your managers are will determine how long you stay on the job.

work life balance is a joke unless you are part time.
advice_management: Actually go back to basics. Learn about the people you work with and show genuine concern. Its not okay to leave us hanging with customer escalation and override our feedback. Also stop taking things personal . The que isn't always important but the technician needs to feel important.

Speed up decision-making process

main_text: I have been working at Apple full-time for less than a year
pros:
People treat each other with respect. Software Engineers are highly valued here. Work life balance is great. The schedule is flexible and no one expects you to be at work during certain hours, unless you have scheduled meetings. The most important thing is to be a good team player and to get the work done in an efficient way. 

There are a lot of growth opportunities for smart people and it’s easy to get promoted if you do a great job. There is no competition between peers. Officially everyone is a software engineer, only your manager knows your level. 

Apple provides you with powerful hardware to get the job done. People are officially allowed to use eligible company devices for personal stuff.

Food at cafes is great and very well prepared. There are a lot of company events, concerts with celebrities coming to Apple and other fun stuff.

Discounts and benefits are incredible. You get a lot of perks. There are several on-site clinics with literally zero wait times. You show up for your appointment, they greet you, take you to your doctor right away.
cons: I can’t think of any
advice_management: Keep up the good work and empower people to do their lives’ best work

cons: Company culture is an attempt at inspiration - you have to be brain dead to accept the inspirational words that are passed down from the corporate environment to retail. It's ambiguous and can be construed into idea other than what's actually intended.
advice_management:
In my experience in several retail stores - 
1) Either too number oriented.
2) Either not focused at all, and grateful for people to show up for work.

Get a grip - have some alignment. This is a company and while regions are different, there should be a set standard for employment. If people don't meet the expectations for the business, fire them. If they do, reward should follow.

You get paid the same for under, and over, performing. This is a problem.

main_text: I have been working at Apple part-time for less than a year
pros: I work in Apple retail, which is a different world from the tech Apple. Pros you always hear about are above average salaries and benefits. This is true. Another pro is being able to cut your teeth in customer interaction roles. Generally people are big fans of the Apple brand.
cons: It seems since Steve Jobs left, Apple has stopped innovating. Almost everyone has an iphone at this point so making sales is harder. They have relied on old retail tactics of upselling insurance and credit cards and upgrade programs as much as possible. That is essentially the only thing they talk about at meetings.  When I took the job i expected a real focus on customer service, which is what they talked about in onboarding, when really the purpose of the store is to get customers to buy insurance and other monthly recurring revenue products.  Also, the reality of transferring from retail to corporate is not nearly as likely as you might think. In fact, unless you want to take a retail job in corporate, it would be wiser to work specifically in the area you want for several years then apply to Apple for it.
advice_management: Advice to retail management. While I understand you are all under pressure to hit the numbers regarding insurance sales, take more time to connect one on one with workers to get to know them. I heard this is what they used to do in the past, but unfortunately don’t do anymore.

main_text: I have been working at Apple full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Get to work from home and are provided with all the equipment you need to do the job. 6% 401k matching. Paid vacation time. Employee stock purchase plan.
cons:
Unless you manage to move up to higher paying positions every few years then it's likely you will be making less over time adjusted for inflation since your merit increases won't keep up with annual inflation. There is an internal discussion regarding this that has been going on for quite some time but has failed to gain any real traction.

Also if you are a chat advisor then your multitasking capabilities need to be excellent since you will be chatting with usually 2 and occasionally up to 3 people simultaneously about different technical issues you will need to diagnose, troubleshoot, and provide a resolution for and you will be evaluated primarily by customer survey feedback. Time is tracked to the second as well which includes your average handle time for each case, time spent finishing logging cases after the chat ends, your breaks, lunches, and punches in and out and if you deviate by more than a few minutes on come of the more important metrics then you'll likely hear from your manager about it.
advice_management: Advocate for the employees to voice their concerns about cost of living adjustments and getting increased pay when the pay scale for the area they are in increases and they don't see any increase since they are already working there.

main_text: I have been working at Apple  for more than a year
pros: The position is at home. The company is AMAZING. There are limitless advancement opportunities. You work with some very cool people and the leadership cares about your development. You may get coaching but you never get battered or belittled. The pay is decent and the benefits include, 401(k) match, stock purchase options, product discounts and discounts on services across many different areas, education assistance, child care assistance, paid vacation, sick time and other time off options, health club Reimbursment or bike cost set off. You get 1.5 time for OT and it's pretty much unlimited as long as you don't exceed 12 hours in a day or 59 total in a week.
cons: The schedule changes every 90 days and you have to bid for your shifts so you never know what you are going to get. This makes it extremely hard to plan your life to far in advance. You are also pretty much assured to work a Saturday or Sunday.
advice_management: The management consists of a team manager and their area manager. Meetings are held over video and chat. main_text: I worked at Apple full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Hardworking, smart and bright employees. Great benefits. Employee discounts are pretty good.
cons:
Well, the retail division has become a weird place to work at. A lot of managers are afraid to be truthful about the nature of the job, which is ultimately sales and technical support with a little bit of training so they dance around tough situations and sometimes aren't honest with the team.

There is a lot of politics involved with promotions. Favoritism is definitely a factor. In some cases it doesn't matter how experienced you are or how knowledgable you are, if you want to get promoted you've got to play the game.

Feedback is something that in most cases isn't used properly. Apple hires very smart people at retail division, then once they are in, the managers don't really know (or sometimes care) how to develop them.

Oh, and don't even think about giving honest feedback to leadership team. Most of them are so drunk from the Kool Aid that instead of listening to you and maybe making changes they they will dismiss your feedback or in some cases make life very difficult so you leave the company on your own.
advice_management: Apple...what happened to you! You used to care, you used to promote fearless feedback, you used to be honest and upfront, you used to be unique, you used to "think outside the box". If you don't change and pay attention to what is happening in individual stores the few good employees you have will eventually leave. people work for you because they care about the brand and company history. Treat them right. Give them a voice.

summary: "Apple will not incentivize and doesn't implement  over site nor a process when. awarding annual bonuses."
main_text: I have been working at Apple full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Job security, will not fire especially if you are paid 50% less than other people doing the same work.
cons:
Biased:  gender, ethnic, disability, age, etc
Human Relations (HR) and Employee Relations (ER) supports all unethical and illegal activity done by management
Management refuses to incentivize or promote certain types of people regardless of how often a person follows up and/or asks how to be incentivized or promoted.
When an employee submits a complaint to HR or ER regarding equal pay issues, HR, ER, and management artificially degrades the complainers performance and sets them up for perpetual failure but doesn't put employee on PIP.
Apple administration will not do anything to stop bias and unequal pay unless a lawsuit and/or EEOC complaint is filed. They are willing to take their chances that they will not get sued or caught. Would rather spend man power on justifying why the company allows bias and unequal pay instead of making sure that all deserving employees are incentivized. 
HR and ER admits that the lack of bonuses for under represented minorities and due to bias is approved by all management including the CIO, Mary Denby.
advice_management: Management should stop breaking employment law and HR and ER should stop enabling them.  I was passed up six years in a row for a cash and RSU bonus and was told every time that although my performance met the high expectations of my role that my manager has "sole discretion" to incentivize whomever he or she wants  and Apple does not implement guidelines on who should receive bonuses.  Human Relations and Employee Relations openly admitted to allowing unequal pay for equal work and said that there is "nothing they can do about it."

main_text: I worked at Apple full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Benefits. Good pay. That's about it.
cons:
Management doesn't care about you at all. They love talking over you and talking you like a child. The whole environment is cancerous honestly. They pride themselves on culture but I never saw it, and managers were never friendly or empathic with me on my personal needs or my medical needs. I told them before my firing that this would really be rock bottom for me and that is kill myself. When they fired me in a webcam session I honestly considered it, and with 2 managers on camera pulled my gun out cocked it and put it to my head on camera. They didn't respond or do anything before I told them I need to leave and shut down my computer. I dare anyone at Apple to pull that session since I know it's recorded, but that's who you're dealing with

You'll be screwed time and again on your schedule so just get used to that. 4 years I was there, never once did I get the schedule I wanted or anything close to it. And you'll be severally chastised for asking questions about it, the last time I did I was mysteriously fired 2 days later. The times for that by the way are 1pm-2am EST. So if you can't work those hours don't bother applying because these people simply don't care. 

No matter what you are the customers punching bag, no it's ands or buts. This company will never have your back. 

Moving up is impossible because for one there's been a hiring freeze since 2016 and two you'll have a million managers in your time each resetting your progress, asking you the same questions as the last until you're ground pulp and give up.
advice_management: All of management needs a massive rehaul including retraining.

main_text: I have been working at Apple part-time for more than a year
pros:
- Pay is okay
- Benefits are good
- Coworkers are pretty cool
- You can kinda pick your schedule
- Scheduled downtime during shifts
cons:
- Micromanagement is rampant in the AppleCare department. Managers do not perform the same job. Their job is to make sure you’re doing your job. That’s it. They don’t understand everything about your role, they’re strictly there to keep eyes on you 24/7. 
- Essentially no room for growth. This is a dead end job. They’ll train you and teach you more skills, but your pay will be exactly the same. 
- You have absolutely no voice. Nothing gets by managers. If you have a problem, don’t expect anyone to do anything about it.
- If you’re a college advisor, you’ll never have a weekend off. I haven’t had a weekend off for 76+ weeks. You can take time off, but you rarely get enough time off to take a weekend off, and a vacation. Use it wisely. 
- Get ready to work. You’re treated like an unskilled factory worker & there is almost no room for error. 
- They don’t focus on strengths. Solely weaknesses. They’ll always find something to nitpick. You’re never “doing good.” Every performance review has a fail on it somewhere.
advice_management: Listen to the employees who actually work.

main_text: I have been working at Apple full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Decent pay. Company name looks good on a resume *outside* of Silicon Valley.
cons:
It doesn't matter how efficient you are--if you work for AppleCare (or other departments, probably), you will be unofficially on-call literally 24/7/365 for constant fire drills (fake emergencies). If you don't answer a phone call at 2 a.m. during a supposedly slow period or bring your computer with you on vacation, you could lose your job.

Upper-level managers have zero tech background and no clue what anyone below them does. You'll get further by smiling than by working hard. So many people are burned out that fully half of the people on our 80-person team are applying for jobs outside of Apple, yet there are never any repercussions for management when anyone manages to escape.

Super racist environment, too. Most Latinx employees work as custodians or in the kitchen, and Black employees are nearly nonexistent.

People keep mentioning health benefits as perks, but what good are benefits and time off if you're not allowed to use any of them?
advice_management: Get over yourselves--get rid of the hierarchical BS. Stop telling employees we're lucky to work 80-hour weeks, then refusing to let us step away for an hour to use our dental insurance. Just because this is Apple, shouldn't mean you shouldn't face repercussions for illegal behavior.

Old timers just sitting there resting and vesting and no one cares about your career, very little movement. Barely any of my coworkers have been progressed to new roles, departments etc. Very typical for folks to be stuck in the same role for years. Lacks innovation after Steve Jobs died.  It’s not Apple it’s run by ex Microsoft Cisco Hp folks bringing their bad culture the company.

summary: "Decent perk package, little room for advancement, high turnaround."
main_text: I worked at Apple full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Enticing perks such as employee stock purchase plan, notable discounts on product, good benefits relative to similar positions at other companies and incentives such as fitness reimbursement ($300 annually).
cons: Extremely difficult to make upward advancement despite the company adamantly encouraging you to make effort to do so. Lots of “lateral” moves to different positions which, despite requiring an entire new interview and hiring process (even from within), do not result in much benefit (monetary or otherwise). There is a huge amount of turnover so they almost expect you to leave once you realize there’s almost nowhere to go but sideways. Annual “merit increases” of 2-5% are the most you can hope for if you do not apply, interview and get hired into an “elevated” position which some stores do not even allow. Don’t get hired at the bottom!
advice_management: More honesty and transparency with regards to setting realistic expectations for employees. Stop “dangling the carrot.”

cons:
You are working retail, after all. Things that go along with that include:
-upset customers
-lazy/entitled coworkers
-retail hours (a LOT of weekends and holidays)
-dealing with ambiguity

Also, you have to REALLY stand out to move up. With massive numbers of staff looking for similar positions (it’s not a job people in elevated roles leave very often), growth becomes very much about performance/influence and can become competitive.
advice_management: Non performing employees place as much, if not more of a burden, on other employees than they do on management. It IS your job to coach and instruct those employees to be a better asset to the team and it shouldn’t be looked over. In my near decade in Apple Retail, leaders tend to look away when they like an employee or no longer want to deal with them, but that gives the impression of favoritism or poor leadership and makes great employees bitter. I’ve lost too many fantastic coworkers for this exact reason alone. Please don’t let it keep happening.

summary: "Can be a good company to work for if you don’t expect to ever go anywhere with the company."
main_text: I worked at Apple full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Good benefits, especially for college students.
cons:
Apple treats its employees as easily replaceable commodities. Don’t expect any loyalty from the company even after working there for over a decade. In fact, they’d rather treat new employees better and the seasoned employees, because new employees are usually still drinking the Apple Kook-aid and are still optimistic about the future. 
Don’t trust HR. Employees don’t realize that HR has a legal obligation to Apple and it’s stakeholders to protect the company and side with the company on employee issues. They are NOT looking out of the employee’s best interest. That is not their job, but they would like you to think they are. Do not confide any confidential information with. They will turn on you and defend Apple rather than admit wrong doing by the company and risk a lawsuit from an employee. I’ve seen many employees forced out of the company because HR turned on them and they became a liability. 
Apple makes it nearly impossible to advance in your career and get a decent raise. To make matters worse, if you’ve been at the company for a long time, newer, less experience employees will probably be making more money than you, because Apple doesn’t value employee retention.
advice_management:
Stop drinking the Kook-aide and actually care about your employees and admin that Apple is not always perfect. 
Your job is not to be defender of Apple if you truly  care about doing the right thing.

summary: "Compliance broker; be in or get out"
main_text: I have been working at Apple
pros:
Great benefits
Smart fun coworkers 
Reasonable hours, for retail
cons:
Stringent adherence to standards
‘Comply’ or don’t advance culture
Lack of opportunities
advice_management:
If you are believe in Your values, act like it.  I was in a situation where The values were ‘everyone is welcome, everyone is included, feedback and honesty is important’.  During a multi-month push on gender and gendered language inclusion training, I mentioned that I don’t feel welcome because I have a military background and I address people as ‘sir or ma’am’.  In a private conversation with the store manager, I was threatened, “learn to be more inclusive or we won’t feel comfortable giving you that promotion we have been working on.”  

I was also lied to when the store manager told me that I had failed to adapt to requests of individuals to address them in a certain way.  Distressed and not liking the feedback, I followed up with the individuals mentioned and they confirmed that I had been improving, and while it was slow at first, there weren’t any issues currently.  So, either the store manager lied, or all three of my coworkers lied.  

Either way, Apple has proven to be a typical corporate entity.  They talk one way because they are required to, but fail to live up to their policies or at least they use their own definition of commonly understood words for things like ‘inclusion’.  

Further more, advancement is only an option if you buy whole sale into extreme left wing identity politics ideology.  If any hint ever emerges that you aren’t in full, complete, and utter compliance, there will be no advancement.  You might be able to drone away in your current role for ever, but you will always be an outsider.  Ironically, ‘in groups and out groups’ was something that I was told must be avoided at all costs.  Yet the extremism with which they require compliance creates out groups be default given how far it goes.

summary: "Strong pay and world class coworkers, terrible work life balance and transparency"
main_text: I worked at Apple full-time
pros: Well above market compensation. Many companies say that they have world-class talent, but from my experience staffing many of the largest tech companies in Silicon Valley, they have some of the sharpest people I've ever met. Incredible buildings and amenities. Ability to learn from incredibly bright coworkers.
cons: Terrible individualistic culture with everyone only looking out for themselves. No work/life balance (I worked about 70 hours a week to meet the near-impossible expectations with no recognition of hard work). Complete lack of transparency. Culture of fear with no feedback. Everyone was terrified every time our Director walked in the room, she was a boss, not a leader. It's the wild west, everyone only looks after themselves and there is no structure whatsoever to give you any guidance. The benefits are surprisingly bad for such a large and prestigious company. Still have to pay for all food/lunches with no snacks in the cafes (I know we are privileged here in the Valley but all of their peers have everything free). AT THE END OF THE DAY, you will learn a ton, get paid a ton and work on some really cool stuff. BUT, this will come at the expense of poor work-life balance, a fear/hierarchical/selfish culture.
advice_management: I know secrecy is a pillar of the culture but the extent the company takes it makes the employees feel isolated and like their work doesn't matter. This is truly a place where you feel like a drop in a bucket. If you don't blindly follow what they are doing, they encourage you to leave.

summary: "Not for those seeking balance in their lives...."
job_title: Former Employee - Senior Global Project Manager
main_text: I worked at Apple full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Better than average compensation and benefits for those willing to go the extra mile.  Those who are willing can take on as much responsibility as they can handle and learn quickly how to move the ball through the management structure.
cons: No work/life balance.  No compassion for those with more Conservative views.  Apple caters to special interest groups and their political views, while putting a tight rein on those who may disagree with their more Liberal perspective.  Not a place to exercise "free speech" and Conservative Values.
advice_management: Level playing field for all employees, and allow the formation of groups from all perspectives.  You demand long hours, so tolerance for all is necessary for everyone to be able to express their opinions, not just those who lean left. main_text: I have been working at Apple full-time for more than a year
pros:
-excellent benefits - healthcare, time away, family leave and education
-choice of work week type - 5days/8 hrs, 4days/10hrs or split shifts 
-working from home 
-all equipment provided 
-acceptable pay
cons:
-Its a call center.  
-Pay is still on the low end considering the job responsibilities and stress from all sides. 
-work schedules change quarterly unless you are in some magically top5% you will NEVER have a weekend off.
-managers can run from super supportive and great, to micromanagers and annoying with threats about how their team is the worst.  
-customer surveys  are part of your stats for scheduling options which are out of your control 
-you said that the focus is on behaviors and not on metrics but you learn about another tool to measure your metrics to "help" you "improve" o your job
-too many pilot projects forced on you 
-customers can be rude, nasty and far beyond entitled 
-lots of outside vendors that make your job difficult because they say and do things clearly against company policy and you get to clean up the mess.
advice_management:
-Continue to align policy and work tools across the support line of business. 
 -Ask employees if they want to be in the endless number of pilot projects. 
- Go back to customers paying for support when they are out of warranty or do not have a support agreement it would reduce the number of nuisance callers.
-train your managers to stop giving thinly veiled threats about how "this team is the lowest performer" and we need to fix it.  Because if you were a good performer and get moved to that team it leaves one wondering who is the poor performer?  Other teammates or the manager.

summary: "Used to be good until greed stepped in"
job_title: Former Employee - Mac+ Tier II AHA
main_text: I worked at Apple full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Good benefits and that's about it.
cons: Apple will heap on additional job responsibilities with no additional pay and no warning. You have no say in it at all. My job description certainly did not include having to take international calls. I was told I would support US and Canada only. Customers will yell at you, belittle you and insult you every day and you are expected to just eat it. Upper management and corporate does not care. This is a billion dollar company who penny pinches with the lower levels of the company (couch cough Applecare). They used to make you feel important, like sending small appreciation gifts. Now, they only do this for retail. They make it clear you are lower than dirt if you are tech support. It's impossible to leave tech support. Once you are there, you are stuck there. And it's a miserable, unappreciated depressing job. I have been out on medical leave and so have hundreds of others caused by the stress of this job. You will be micromanaged to within an inch of your life. You can do everything perfect, resolve issues and make the customers love you and it will never, ever be good enough. You will be lied to consistently. You will be ignored, criticized and your self-esteem will take more hits than a stoner at 420. By the time you leave this job, you will be a shell of your former self.
advice_management: Hire management for  AppleCare who actually knows what they are doing. They ALL need to be fired.You cannot save money by simply making your current employees do more rather than hire more people. All you are doing is burning out the real talent that you have.

pros: Benefits are amazing. Seriously. That’s why it’s hard to leave.

But, it’s felt more about selling phones, AppleCare, and getting people signed up for the iPhone upgrade plan. Truthfully, anyone could do the job I was doing with the right training, and I was wasting talents at a company I’d never grow in.

I’m sure a corporate job would be different, but I’d never work for Apple retail again.
advice_management: Let people pursue the area they want. I wanted to work in inventory; they wanted me to be a technician or expert. In two years, the conversation never pointed toward me moving to an inventory role. I never felt heard or taken seriously for my own strengths and goals.

summary: "Love the company, very poor management, lots of cronyism"
main_text: I have been working at Apple full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Apple’s philosophy, concern for the environment, inclusivity and products are to be admired. Benefits are good, and they are a class act.
cons: What is unfortunate in the Apple, PIE group is how many truly bad managers there are and how rampant cronyism is within the company. HR issues are handled poorly if they get any response at all. As a result, you have to put up with bullying, favoritism and as a PM, you absolutely have no voice;  your concerns carry zero weight. People get promoted because of who brought them into the company (there is a large Yahoo contingent currently within the PIE PMO). There are PMs who barely show up to work or who barely do competent work and they will die at Apple and continue to earn favorable reviews. If you’re not in the clique that matters, you’ll be shown the door. If you talk to your manager’s manager, you’re screwed, because those two people are friends.
advice_management: Stay away from allowing managers to hire groups if their friends. It doesn’t allow for a fair playing field and creates resentment amongst employees.

If you travel for the holidays, DO NOT anticipate getting paid time off for that.  From November thru December is a no no for vacation time.  No Work/Life balance.
advice_management: Stand up for yourselves and challenge corporate in how they think a store should be run

summary: "IS&T is a terrible terrible place to work as engineers !!"
main_text: I have been working at Apple full-time for more than a year
pros:
- Apple brand on resume if you care about these sort of superficial things. 
- Product discounts
cons:
- IS&T is the worst place to work for engineers. Swamped with 3rd party contractors, indian body-shop mostly, management treats them terribly. Rude, unprofessional and unethical work culture. Senior leadership within IS&T are terrible, egoistic megalomaniac, with zero leadership skills. They don't know how to lead by example.
- There is no place for engineers here in this group. Rampant politics and horrible work culture. Managers in this group are nothing but "project managers", who have no technical / engineering acumen, and have no eye towards architecture, code or good engineering practices. They treat engineers like second class citizens. These managers have no interest in career growth and development of their employees. All they care about is themselves and their RSU refreshers, appeasing their bosses anyway possible to get there.
- Most of the teams in IS&T build internal and corporate tools/applications. and they are dismal at that, from infrastructure to development processes, terrible..terrible !! You won't be working on anything world changing. 
- If you think you can change groups easily, you are sadly mistaken. It is very difficult to change groups/departments within Apple. You need to let your manager of your interest first, then go through the entire recruitment process, as if you are an external candidate, and if for whatever reason, you do not end up landing that new position, you would face extreme retaliation in your current team, your current manager would screw your career up. You would be ostracized, and he/she would make sure you have no future left in Apple. 
- IS&T has a bad reputation within apple, and every other group within apple treats IS&T folks that way. Other engineering groups are treated better. In short, apple has this subtle class-based culture. Not everyone is treated equally and respect.

If you are an engineer and thinking about joining Apple and IS&T assuming you would be able to do amazing engineering work, you are sadly mistaken. IS&T is the place where engineers come to destroy their career. My personal advice - Stay away from this group.
advice_management: Cleanup IS&T leadership and management. Get rid of poor performing managers and whose team has high turnover, and bring some engineering discipline within the group. Advice to Apple HR :- If you want engaging, motivated and happy employees, make it easy for people to change groups or departments, without this system/process that fosters retaliation and harassment.

main_text: I have been working at Apple part-time for more than a year
pros:
Great benefits even for part-timers 
Stock Employee Purchase Program
Discounts on products
Good team work culture
Customer focus is beyond strong
cons:
The “but”
... NO work/life balance, hard to get multiple days off unless requested several months out or you need to swap.
... be prepared for an onslaught of nights (sometimes till 10PM), weekends and holidays.
... constant “call-outs” sick leaving existing product and tech specialists with heavy workloads with little time to breathe between customers and difficult to leave when your shift is over.
... no commissions on products and heavy emphasis on selling Apple Services. Everything is tracked by product and service and micro managed.
... Apple retail expects way to much for under $20/hour.
advice_management:
... Get rid of the email computer alias “Merlin” when time is approved/rejected creating a shifty environment.
... Reward employees or incentivize specialists to go extra mile; ie; selling services and just don’t expect it from college age hipsters that have no sales experience.
... hire enough people so you can alternate weekend and holiday time off to give floor specialists at least one weekend off each month. The present format burns out the tech or product specialist out to the point of heavy call-outs.
... try to develop an EasyPay system that will reduce the constant signing in to engage customers.

main_text: I worked at Apple full-time for more than a year
pros: Exposure to Apple's media products that are gaining traction quickly
cons:
If you see an opening in the AMP (Apple media products) or iTunes analytics or data science team, and you are a non-white analytics professional who actually wants to grow (not become a reporting machine), avoid it at all cost.

The AMP analytics org is highly political and hostile towards other departments besides business and marketing who fund them. It’s now managed by a bunch of white males who took power but now don’t know how to bring in analytics talents with real industry experience or build a team that can serve all the reporting needs across the company. These guys have been at Apple for most of their careers, so they only know how to churn out reports with whatever data is available but don’t really know how to contextualize analytics insights. They’ve either hired query monkeys or diversity hires who are less than competent, while talents with real leadership and industry experience have departed. 

The culture of the teams within the org is finding scapegoats when they make mistakes, favoring and promoting white males, and managers taking all the credit for their team members’ hard work. There’s little opportunity to really grow in terms of your skill set and leadership, because everybody in the org now just kind of fake it til’ they make it.

Data engineering is extremely slow in providing support, and the backlog keeps getting pushed around from one team to another, so no real roadmap plus frustrated stakeholders.

Retail environment is a game of favorites no matter how you slice the cake. Popularity beats talent. Interviews are only formalities. If you're lucky enough to have the majority of the leadership team like you, you can maybe move up. 

Each market is different in their approach and it's a roll of the dice. I worked for three different markets and the last one was all driven by numbers. My advice is that if your ideas aren't being heard or considered and you're being driven to drive sales, move on. It's easy to get stuck here and while it's not a bad place to get stuck, you deserve to be somewhere that gives you growth potential and a feeling of true contribution.

summary: "Very hit or miss, often poorly managed"
main_text: I have been working at Apple full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
If you're fortunate enough to land on the right team, you'll get design / engineering / hardware resources and be able to do meaningful work.
Benefits like health insurance, 401k matching, stock purchase plan are good.
cons:
Things are very decentralized and there's little visibility outside of your team.
Some teams just struggle to get resources. The company is massive but only seems to really care about or prioritize certain projects that executives are interested in.
Tons of bureaucracy. Does not feel like you can grow a career here past the lowest levels. Promotions are extremely difficult to get.
Most people are focused on their own careers, meeting deadlines, getting their managers off their backs. People like to say they care about the customer but most meetings are just about getting stuff out the door on time, not about quality products.
Employee perks are nonexistent. You will find yourself being told that the perks of working for Apple are working for Apple.
Parking is atrocious. I spend 30+ minutes a day parking.
advice_management: You need to care more about the product than delivering features on time, and reward engineers who care about the product, not rank them based on arbitrary measures of impact. Promotions shouldn't require an engineer to sell their soul, stop caring about customers, and do meaningless work just to impress executives.

summary: "One of the best companies you can work for, if you get the chance."
main_text: I worked at Apple full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Great work environment. Growth focused.  If you want to become a overall better person they provide the tools and guidance.  Work hard, play hard mentality.   Getting in at Apple isn't easy so it helps to know someone and they refer you.  Some of the best leaders around work there, but not all leaders share the same vision.  Work/life balance is very important to them and they give you lots of time to take off.  Employee purchase plan is also nice, but could be better.  Overall I had one of the best working experiences with this company.
cons: Not the most autonomy, although the managers try their best to convince you.  Extremely competitive to move up, can become political.  I've heard pay has improved although it definitely could have been more competitive for the work and the results.  Depending on what market you are located in, there can be an extreme push for results.
advice_management: Be as transparent as possible.  Continue to invest in your people.  Communicate as effectively as you can.

summary: "They used to pay me to be an elite computer technician, now they pay me to clean earwax out of people's headphones."
main_text: I have been working at Apple full-time for more than 10 years
pros: The healthcare and medical leave benefits are great.
cons: Leadership is much more focused on hitting numbers than they are with fostering an engaging and fun work environment. The retail experience used to be chaos with a good dose of enthusiasm, but now is chaos with a good dose of confusion.
advice_management:
We are supposed to be "the crazy ones. The misfits. The rebels. The troublemakers. The round pegs in the square holes. The ones who see things differently."
However, if we raise concerns we are squelched. We can no longer wear what we want and display individuality. We are cogs in a ghastly machine that has become so massive and so self-congratulating, that it's impossible to effect change from this level anymore.
There's no advice I can give you. Apple has so much money that they will continue to shamble on long after the ghost of innovation and whimsy has finally escaped the gaping maw of this company.

AMAZING HEALTH BENEFITS. Maternity leave was stellar.

cons:
Retail leadership can treat their roles as if they're literally curing cancer, making them seem hard to relate to and holier than thou.
Difficulty in communication transparency for the team members that aren't the ideal "perfect employee". Lack of confrontation skills keep leaders really vague on true opportunities that individuals needs to correct in order to advance.
No true time and attendance policy - holding those accountable for terrible attendance to work is not consistent from store to store because certain stores can have managers who stick to a guide, while other stores can have leadership teams with no backbones and are too wrapped up in their own agendas to really care about the stores.
Leaders can know WHO the problematic contributors are, but have minimal resources to truly performance manage those people out. That creates a toxic culture of those problematic ones campaigning to bring other passive mindsets to the detractor ways.
advice_management: Remember your greatest asset is your people. Invest in them wisely, or else they'll pack up and leave. Remember that you're not reinventing the wheel and treat every day in your own store as if Tim himself were watching you.

job_title: Former Employee - Apple At Home Advisor
main_text: I worked at Apple part-time for more than a year
pros: Some good benefits including 401k, product discounts, and stock option. Some flexibility in scheduling as a part of the College Program, as they set your schedule by semester according to the schedule of classes you submit to them. There are opportunities for educational reimbursement for qualifying courses. If you like apple branded swag they definitely give you a lot of it!
cons: Performance is based on metrics that are not necessarily reflective of your work  - they send vague email surveys to customers asking them how satisfied they were with their call experience. Of course, if they are out of warranty (majority of customers) and we cannot help them they are not going to be satisfied. One or two of these negative surveys will really impact your metrics. Escalation to Tier 2 will also impact your metrics even if it is truly beyond your control (bugs in new OS update, faulty product, etc). There is a lot of push to sell stuff to customers. Managers only care about the numbers. It is a very corporate culture that can often feel cultish. The requirement to work on Christmas/holidays is unfortunate. Very low wages in the College Program. I have heard from other employees that management could view your screens and access your camera without your knowledge, which is terrifying but I am not sure of how true it is. This position is often emotionally draining, as most people who call are upset about experiencing a technical issue, and a lot of them will take it out on you. Obviously, as an at-home position, it can be quite isolating.
advice_management: Place less emphasis on metrics, which are often skewed by one or two bad CSATs that were sent by angry customers who were out of warranty or whose problems could not be resolved due to issues outside of the advisor's control. Technical training was somewhat adequate, but the position really is about providing customer care. More training for actually dealing with customers/managing expectations would be helpful but I understand the limitations in providing training for that - it is very situational. However, more support could be given to advisors in general.

summary: "Everything is about a relentless, soulless drive for sales - even tech support"
main_text: I have been working at Apple part-time for more than 3 years
pros: Coworkers are always fantastic, everyone is very collaborative, there's a very good atmosphere amongst your peers.
cons:
Management claims to care about work-life balance, but then schedules you for early morning and late night meetings on weekend days even if it's outside of your availability. 

There's also zero room for growth in the company unless you're willing to sell your soul out to metrics and jump through every flaming hoop that your connection manager demands of you. Over the past several years, the Genius Bar has been progressively overrun and infested with a rabid sales culture. The job of a TS is now more about peddling and pushing services and building leads for the business team to follow up on than it is about actual troubleshooting. It's absolutely miserable, and the constant badgering by connection managers who claim to care about your "development" while simultaneously degrading you if you don't meet sales metrics expectations only makes things worse. You are able to submit feedback to leadership on a bi-annual basis about ways the workplace can improve, but I have yet to see management ever make any meaningful course corrections to match the responses they get.
advice_management: You are the reason why people quit this company to take their professional pursuits elsewhere. Ordering pizza every few months for the team doesn't make up for the degrading experience of having to perform the role of a salesman when you applied to do tech support and help people.

summary: "No promotion opportunities, No incentive to perform well. Be prepared to stay in the same role for a long time"
main_text: I have been working at Apple full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Fun work environment/colleagues, Ok benefits but not as good as they used to be.
cons:
At the start I was really motivated and really liked working at Apple, after 3 years...not so much
There are no opportunities for growth. Promotions are not in any way based on performance/contribution. 
As one the top performers I constantly get passed on any promotions, declined on interviews e.g,  which demotivates extremely. 
Hard work is not recognized or valued. Be prepared to be stuck in a position for a very long time. If you want a company where you are valued and promoted on performance Apple is not the company to work for.

It's sad that after working there for over 3 years and being one of the best in my group there is no way for growth/development and no valuation for performing at peak levels consistently.
advice_management: Value your high performing employees and take performance into account when interviewing internal candidates

summary: "Great pay, benefits and people. Making a career is more difficult."
main_text: I have been working at Apple full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Great training, pay, benefits and people. Working from home is a solid opportunity.
cons:
Advancement in my time (5yrs) seems impossible unless you have the right people backing you or know people. Connections vs capability.
Most experience outside of Apple doesn't seem to matter, its again what you know internally and who you know.
Some managers seem too far removed from the role of the employees they manage.
You can tell who is working for you, the customer and the company and those who are either complacent and/or just there for a check.
advice_management:
Look at the teams and employees and really see who cares about what they do. Maybe in addition to managers have ORG leaders who help with real career advancement, yes I know you offer PTS, but most of the time its so short and generic. Don't be afraid to retain or release people who don't care about the job. 
I honestly love this company and hoped to make a career here, but in being blunt if I'm not kissing up to the right people, or have a TM or AM that really wants to back me. My time and experience doesn't matter.

main_text: I have been working at Apple full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
- High paying for retail work
- Decent training
- Diverse staff
- Stable company
cons:
- Extremely limited advancement opportunities
- Very poor raises
- Horrific work / life balance
- Highly political ladder climbing structure 
- In the retail environment, we get treated like garbage by our customers on a daily basis. The higher-than-normal retail salary isn't worth it for how poorly we are treated (by customers).
advice_management: Stop making people play games to move ahead. Promote hard workers - not 'yes' people and butt-kissers. Value your retail team and pay them better (Reserve Stock Units are not what we want for raises). Follow through on the values you talk about all the time (work / life balance, advancement opportunities).

job_title: Current Employee - Senior Customer Service Representative
main_text: I have been working at Apple full-time for more than 5 years
pros: I get to work from home. High autonomy and the ability for self management. Friendly work environment. Freedom of self expression style wise and a great employee community.
cons: Constant change in structure and a lot of responsibility for others mistakes. No upfront mention of pay in job roles so the pay can vary greatly. I know 3 people with similar experience who started and maintain pay at least 5 dollars an hour higher for the same role. Low yearly pay increases for excellent performance. Performance structure is very dependent on relationships with direct manager.
advice_management: Pay structure and raises need to be re-evaluated. Also, there needs to be a way for management to review customer reviews in a similar way to peer review taking into account the entire interaction neutrally. This would also allow removal of reviews in error.

summary: "Apple IS&T, toxic place, not actually Apple"
main_text: I worked at Apple full-time for more than a year
pros: You get Apple on your resume.  Engineers are nice for the most part.
cons:
Apple IS&T is the worst, most toxic environment at Apple.  When you work here, you do not really work for Apple, you are like outsiders.  It is truly scary that a place like this can exist at a company like Apple.  You should not join.  Good people cannot fix broken environments.  The place is broken because of legacy culture from the top.

They will make it sound nice and paint a nice picture with words, but once you get there, you will realize you are trapped in a bait and switch, career suicide.   They could get sued for this.  Many managers are mean, incompetent, or  aggressive slave drivers.  Stay away.
advice_management:
You at least need to overhaul / modernize IS&T, and put in real technical leadership.   Imagine if this were a place that naturally attracted top infra talent, like Google, Facebook or Netflix? 

The whole business partner vs IS&T partner creates never ending division and attracts mean  / micro managers and results in a diversity and inclusion issue.  Imagine for a moment if the business partners actually hired the engineers they depend on.  Or do they not have the technical acumen?  Or is the work too unattractive / dirty?  Do you really need 30 contractors when 2 FTE engineers would get the job done?

You can do better than this.

summary: "Not Sustainable - You feel disposable and used"
main_text: I worked at Apple full-time for less than a year
pros: You get to work at "Apple". Whatever that means to you. To me it meant nothing.
cons:
It is a high stress job involving travel to China. Since Apple products are assembled in China, thats where most of the action happens from a Supply Chain and Operations perspective. My days started early with calls with teams in Europe. During the day i was working with teams in US. From evening until night, I was on calls with teams in China as you get a lot of requests. It was a 24x7 thankless job. If you have time to manage two projects, you'll always have four. You are not innovating or designing cool products in Supply Chain. You are only making sure these products are ready when customers want it. The only differentiator in performance is the number of hours you put in. 
1. There are not many people with great backgrounds here. Most of the folks are from supply chain backgrounds from random less reputed companies or business schools for whom having Apple on the CV is a huge uplift. Some people with good background are at senior positions who joined Apple in the early days and they are enjoying their million dollar valuation of stocks.
2. Leadership: Apple loves engineers. Most people in managerial roles got promoted from IC engineering roles and do not have an iota of aura or leadership qualities. They are very arrogant and don't care about people.
3. The work is very stressful with aggressive targets and you have to always be on top of China. I have seen people break down in meetings. Many people had health issues and were always looking to exit. Having alcohol on your table is common. There is no time for personal life. When you join you are given a paper that says 'the work you will do is so great that people dont mind spending their weekends here'. Thats a hint. LOL
4. Average employee turnover time is ten months. It is just not sustainable and that is why you can always find tons of open GSM roles on the Apple website. Apple is now a big organization and it is tough to move up and steer the politics.  
5. Culture: There is no culture. Every person is on his/her own. There is no collaboration. No one likes to share anything and people keep fighting to prove their point. You'll be doing everything yourself from scratch everytime and that will add to the hours and frustration. In my team, people fought for air time and tried to make loud conversations with team mates when manager was around. It was fake environment. The director would come to happy hour in team area for two minutes and take a mental head count of who all were present and who all were not participating in this 'team event'.  
6. Even with Apple salary, you'll just make your ends meet as this is one of the most expensive part of the world. You will never be able to afford to buy a house. You'll shell out all your money on rent and survival stuff. 
7. Career Opportunities: Depends on your relations. However every project is secretive and that limits your opportunities. Also, you can only move within your vertical. Moving to Applecare is not possible. Also, my manager dint help me in any way to find a new role when i wanted to change roles. Thats common. Also, you'll be hired because you can do the job well. Apple will not invest in your to develop new skills. You'll be doing the same work your entire life. 

In short working at Apple involves high stress, all your hours, no new skills development and little savings. The only thing you get is an Apple name on your CV. Is it worth it? You decide for yourself. International folks with MBA, this role is a trap and its tough to get out. There are better options out there. Check out how this role is rated on transparentcareer and you'll get more data points.
advice_management:
1. There are proven models available like the 28-28 or the 14-14 in oil and gas for operations roles. With 150B$ cash, if you hire two people to do the same job, your cash will not drop by even a single digit. It'll still be rounded as 150B$. 
2. Dont treat your employees as you treat your suppliers, i.e. with arrogance. Invest in them and train them as humans and not slaves. 
3. Treat your suppliers better.

main_text: I have been working at Apple full-time for more than a year
pros:
Great pay and benefits considering the line of work.
You get to meet and work with a lot of great people.
Nature of the job leads you to gain a lot of personal growth in developing interpersonal skills.
Typically, leadership and team members will have your back when it comes to support.
Helps develop emotional IQ.
Sounds a little cliched, but there are times when you and a customer will truly connect and you will feel their gratitude deeply. This can be quite overwhelming sometimes (in the best way).
cons:
It's retail, so can be both physically and emotionally draining at peak times.
They make it so it feels good where you're at which can lead to a risk of getting complacent and next thing you know you've been there longer than you intended.
While there is somewhat of a clear path to advancement, management can lean toward favoritism in lieu of job qualifications when it comes to promotions.
advice_management: Take the time to calmly look at those you lead and appreciate them as people. The leadership (at least at our store) is typically focused on results and/or customer experience. Employee experience can be forgotten at times and some of them just need to know they are being seen and appreciated for the often times challenging work.

They're more likely to hire someone from starbucks who has no idea what they're doing than promote someone who's been there forever.

main_text: I have been working at Apple part-time for more than 3 years

The pay and benefits are great compared to anywhere else I could work part time. Discounts for friends and family. Very flexible scheduling. Management actually cares about you. Your store becomes like a second family. Its easy to move up if you do well and communicate your successes to your direct manager. Its good to brag about yourself so that your work gets noticed. You can also do career experiences in Cupertino. Some people even go from retail to corporate just by doing a career experience depending on your background.
cons: There are few stores so sometimes you have to commute to your location. The stores are often very cold. Robberies have become more prominent in the last year. Customers can be very rude.
advice_management: Don't give in too easily to the demand of the customer especially if it conflicts with what the specialist told the customer. I wish it was easier to get weekends off. Its hard because you have to request time off nearly two months in advance to get it off.

summary: "Good luck advancing if you’re not a woman or minority."
main_text: I worked at Apple part-time for more than 3 years
pros: Ok pay, great healthcare and perks, fun atmosphere and coworkers, low pressure sales.
cons: Scheduling is horrific even with a full-time employee managing it. You won’t get weekends off even if you have religious obligations, (they should prepare to be sued). Once hired as part-time your chances of becoming full-time even if you out perform your peers is very low, unless you kiss the right butt, or you’re a minority. The store manager even verbalized in multiple meetings that “she wants us to refer women and minorities because we have enough white guys”. Because the store manager came from Target, she seems to get a kick out of filling other leadership positions with external candidates instead of promoting from within. Extremely high turnover because of favoritism and poor management decisions.
advice_management: Promote from within. You can’t be at a “Pro Level” if your last job was at a Home Depot and you’re not even comfortable selling a Mac. Store management needs an overhaul before you get sued for the ignorance that is spewed by management.

summary: "Amazing place to work with few downsides"
main_text: I worked at Apple full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Amazing benefits, discounts, helps build resume and interviewing skills for after you leave, they’re always innovating and changing. So you may he the first to test drive new technologies or retail concepts. Corporate is full of genuinely good people who care about creating the best place to shop and work. A lot of effort goes into keeping it fun and engaging. There’s a large leadership team at each store so chances are you’ll connect well with at least one of them.
cons: It gets VERY stressful in the holidays, if you don’t understand the company culture, it can be tough. They’re always innovating and sometimes it means lots of change with marginal results. Not always but when it sucks, it sucks. It’s like any other job. Despite incredible training and effort from corporate, at the store level it can break down.
advice_management: Each store is different. I worked at 3. Some managers were amazing and truly cared about developing people, and some were poor at managing a high performing team. Keep doing NPP and seeking feedback, and act on it. If employees report trends or opportunities for management, look into it. Sometimes we’d go a full year before any real action plans to correct bad behavior from management were revealed or implemented.

main_text: I worked at Apple full-time for more than a year
pros: A great group of people to work with, good benefits, great communication from management
cons: I had a work from home position, Apple redefines the term overbearing. Every single thing was monitored down to the second. How long were you on a call, how long was your mouse idle on your screen, how long did it take you to type up notes. Everything was tracked, I worked a 4x10 schedule and it was 10 hours of sitting at a desk with barely any time to breath let alone take a break to even go to the restroom. Management based every decision on their "metrics" which record things like customer review, average call time, etc... but they do not show the difficulty of the case or the spur of the moment issues that can arise
advice_management: take better care of your work from home employees, there needs to be a better work-life balance. Metrics are not everything!

summary: "Human Beings work here. Increase pay to "Adult Wage" instead of "Living Wage""
main_text: I have been working at Apple full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Remote position; iMac provided for work; stipend for monthly internet access; opportunities for growth, if you want self-explore and ask questions and request interviews of other teams within Applecare, Apple Retail, and Apple [ Corporate ].
Benefits begin day one. Benefits are amazing, and extensive. Wellness matters here.
cons:
Compensation. 

Non-manufacturing role Corporate employees are limited to on-site positions in cities with eye popping real-esate rent and sales prices.
advice_management:
1.  Human Beings work here. Increase pay to "Adult Wage" instead of "Living Wage".  Pay needs increase substantially for Applecare and Apple Retail employees. We are the first point of contact for our customers, and, as expected, our level of knowledge and competency set's the standard for call centers and retail employees in all industries. 
 
 2. If multiple complaints filed against abusive managers, provide coaching / training to said managers. If more complaints continue, reassign to a non-leadership role, or, promote manager to "customer".  It's rare, but abusive humans exist everywhere. 

3. Create an open and clear path for employees of Apple Retail and Applecare to enter positions in Apple Corporate.  Right now, it's best described as a "black box" experience. 

4. Increase remote positions within corporate. The standard has been set with Applecare remote workers. It's time to change the 20th century paradigm of having to "commute" to a work place when your role does not involve manufacturing.

main_text: I worked at Apple part-time for more than 5 years
pros: The people, benefits, and discounts. Can be easy to transfer to another store if you're moving.
cons: The hours are ridiculous if you're part-time. You'll still work 5 days a week but only 4 or 5 hours a day with some periods of working close to full-time hours until they need to scale you back so you don't automatically get moved to a full-time employee. You have to deal with some of the worst customers who are ungrateful, rude, entitled, and will snap at anything. It can be near impossible to get promoted depending on the store you work in. If you work in a popular store, the role you're applying for will likely go to a transfer instead so. The pay raises and reviews are an absolute joke. The company will act like you are the most important thing ever, but I think this really only applies if you work at corporate. You'll spend all your time trying to get into corporate but you'll have to be there for a long time, kiss a lot of behind, or you'll be stuck in retail forever.
advice_management: Listen to your employees. Trust what they are saying and treat them like humans. If you did this, you likely wouldn't have as high of a turn over rate and will retain employees longer.

main_text: I have been working at Apple full-time for more than a year
pros:
-wonderful products that can truly improve how people work
-huge aspirations to impact the enterprise
cons:
-commission structure nebulous at best, not inclusive of sales from all channels
-sales governance seemingly not concerned with resolving issues that impact commission (work at snail's pace) 
-leadership more concerned with the process and results, not so much the individual employees
-add to the team not just people managers used to work with at their previous stop
-add to the team people that are not afraid to smile, show some personality and gregariousness. We're on the same team, aren't we? 
-high turnover, although that seems to have abated somewhat
advice_management:
Employees should come before the process and the numbers! Check ego and pride at the door. Serve your team and you'll see results. Managers, get to know your team. It's ok to say hi once in a while--authentically. 

Start here...get to know them, then you'll understand what buttons need to be pressed to get the best performance from each individual on your team.

main_text: I worked at Apple full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
**This is from the perspective of an on-site (Cupertino) corporate employee's perspective. Does not apply to home advisors or retail.

- Legitimizes your professionalism and the skills it takes to acquire to get to that point in your career. 
- The people - if you're fortunate you will meet some great people, find a mentor and keep in touch regardless of who you call your employer. 
- Some teams are very flexible with great work/life balance. I was fortunate to be part of several teams like this. 
- Ability to move around within the company (laterally).
- Product discounts (because if you were getting paid a higher salary than Apple, you wouldn't be accepting the offer right?)
- Pads your resume nicely
- You get to say you work at Apple and make mom and dad proud, if that's your thing
cons:
- Average Salary (they know folks like saying they work there and ego wins most of the time)
- After a few years, politics will become very evident and part of it is keeping the status quo (i.e. innovation has declined you could apply the proverb here "The nail that sticks out...")
- Inconsistent policies within organizations (Some teams within the same division/organization are 9-5, others are flexible - up to your manager)
- Apple has become that which it once stood against (an inevitability)
- They've hired third party contractors to police internal policies that may or may not be published
advice_management: No advice, they're doing great. However, the inevitable will happen and it's coming in the form of a small scrappy company led by an eccentric CEO with a vision and product that will disrupt the world.

pros:
- Nice benefits that start on day one.
- PPO health insurance, term life insurance, 401k, on site gym.

cons:
- Typical call center environment, they pump up that the sky is the limit but from what I saw, it’s not the case.
- Employees have been there for over ten years and are still not in any type of management position. 
- You can rotate around to other departments, but mostly to another support role. 
- Little creativity involved, very repetitive work.
- Micromanaged, micromanaged, micromanaged!

Call center work isn’t for me which I came to terms with while working here. Your experience may differ, I know some people really enjoyed it there while others didn’t.
advice_management: Evaluate the strengths, skills and personalities of employees and place them in positions that they will excel in.

main_text: I have been working at Apple part-time for more than 3 years
pros:
- Amazing benefits even for part-time employees
- Work with a lot of diverse people
- On-the-job training
cons:
They ask so much more of you than a typical retail job of this level but don't back it up with raises OR respect. It also seems like the management isn't hired from the same quality of employees. Unilaterally, I watched all the amazing managers leave our store for better jobs. 

That's what happens here. If you're good at your job and you care about what you do, management will wring you for all you're worth until you're nothing but a desiccated husk. The smart ones will leave before that happens.

The ones that succeed here are the ones who will "drink the koolaid" or, as we put it, "the Apple juice" - free thinkers need not apply.
advice_management: RESPECT. YOUR. EMPLOYEES.

main_text: I worked at Apple part-time for less than a year
pros:
Awesome benefits
PTO for vacations and sick time is added every check
Discounted Apple products
Great opportunity to move up if you're GOOD and consistent in your position
cons:
Micro managed SEVERELY, someone is watching your every move every second and it's documented
Apple wants you to be a robot, they want to MOLD you, if you can't be molded i.e quiet, passive, not argumentative or opinionated you're a perfect fit, if not? Stop while you're ahead
Apple is ALWAYS understaffed for customer service, be aware. Retail store sends customers to YOU, even if you send them to the store. The stores do nothing but repairs and sell products.
The sole component of Apple is their customer service, you're are the glue. If you're not the best glue, understand you will be stressed because someone will remind you daily.
Not worth it if you're a college student, unless you're graduating.
Benefits do not outweigh the emotional and verbal abuse by management.
advice_management: Stop lying to your employees and teaching them that you're a top tier company that doesn't make sense. summary: "Remnants of what it used to be... but with enormous career benefits"
job_title: Former Employee - Senior User Experience Designer III
main_text: I worked at Apple full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
From a senior designer perspective across multiple orgs and 5 years
- resume booster / career validation
- great if your satisfied with the status quo and want a paycheck to retire with
- you can say you work at apple if that sort of thing matters
- if you get on the right team, there are awesome people there
cons:
- inconsistent creative direction or vision
- groups within the same org can function 110% different ranging from the 9-5 group to the laid back results oriented group.
- politics and stereotypes internally abound. Was “let go” after a lengthy investigation on a violation of a policy enacted 2 years after I was hired. No psa of new zero tolerance policies, or so they said. 
- certain orgs acquire agencies and they bring that dynamic with them. Most of the time they’re siloed which is good but if you’ve been part of an agency you probably don’t want that culture in your day to day anymore
- if you want benefits (snacks, stocked fridge) , salary at the higher end of the scale and have an impact on what you’re contributing as a designer, this might not be the place for you. If you just had a baby, bought a house, need stability or building your resume now is a good time. But the culture shift will catchup with the rumors as well as the numbers in the coming years.

No hard feelings, great time while I was there and wouldn’t change a thing. Easy finding an engaging mid 6 figure position elsewhere. Companies also match RSUs you might’ve lost out on. Mostly I miss the people and my team, but unfortunately losing faith in where the company is headed... I wouldn’t accept a position again considering the current climate within most major design orgs.
advice_management: Some of you are awesome and I owe a lot of my success to you. I’ll be forever indebted. Others don’t have the qualifications to be where they are, but got there bc of politics and nepotism. Thanks to the former!

main_text: I worked at Apple part-time for more than a year
pros: Company always hires great people. Very rarely will you work with people who don’t pull their weight. Great benefits. Pays well for what it is.
cons: Corporate keeps technicians in the dark about issues with the products and then expects them to do their dirty work explaining it to the customers with little to zero info. Forcing “part time” employees to have 30 hours of availability during the week. Rule school or your second job out! The work is brutal. Customers are mostly either neutral or nasty. Very rarely did I find myself actually being able to solve problems or make people happy. Leaders dangle carrots in front of employees for promotions they won’t see for a long time. Benefits are great but they aren’t worth it in the big picture. Trust me, giving up the benefits is a small price to pay for sanity. I’ve been much happier since I quit. Work there for a year, lock in your passion in the mean time, and then get out of there! I am not writing all this out of bitterness. I left on good terms and am still re-hireable. I worked at three different locations and just want people to know what to expect under the hood. You WILL encounter these issues.
advice_management: Relate to the employees better. Be transparent. Explain issues with the products in scientific detail so the employees can give good solid info to the customers about why they are paying $300 plus dollars for something that isn’t their fault. The employees are smart and want direct answers. No more blowing smoke, please...for their sake.

summary: "Low unrealistic pay far below market price during interview"
main_text: I worked at Apple

And I have been progressing fairly well in pay since then.  I told them what I was making at the time of interview, which is way over the $80K Apple offered.  The interviewer's counter offer was "But we are Apple."
advice_management: Do you not know the pay for the right candidate on the market place or was you just wasting my time collecting market info.  If Apple insists compensating at a rate far below the market rate, good luck finding an experienced candidate.

main_text: I worked at Apple  for less than a year
pros: Apple offers amazing benefits and pay compared to other jobs for college students. There is also a lot of opportunity for career advancement within the company. The positives definitely outweigh the negatives in this job though.
cons: As with every customer service job, you have to deal with some mean people over the phone but that is expected. Also, you have to submit a preferred schedule for work but it is not guaranteed that you get the schedule you desire. Being a college student in this position, getting a good schedule for your class load is of utmost priority. main_text: I have been working at Apple full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Working at Apple is a unique experience that will be like no other company. You work with some of the most amazing people who are talented in a wide range of talents. You learn so much from your team members you'll always utilize them as a resource and they soon become family. The culture here is definitely unique and coming from a commissioned background, as far as sales goes, cut-throat and vindictive behaviors aren't encouraged. Moving up and growing is fairly simple, work hard, build a good rapport, and your work should be noticed. The benefits are amazing: top of the line health, dental, and vision insurance, education and fitness reimbursements (if you work near or at a campus they typically have gyms on campus for roughly $5), medical consultation form Stanford University, 3rd party corporate discounts, RSU and ESPP (Employee Stock Purchase Program) and so much more! Every few months there's something called NPP (Net Promoter for out People) in which the company asks us for our feedback for things to implement change.
cons: Working in retail is tough. The leadership team can sometimes micromanage while not assuming positive intent which is frustrating. My local leadership team tells you "you own your own development" but give you no direction or coaching. When first starting with the company you get a lot of training for your role, but unfortunately no training around our company's amazing benefits and how to utilize them, and when it's time to use them you're typically scrambling to get a hold of your resources.

main_text: I worked at Apple full-time for more than 3 years

cons: Leadership is lacking over the years.  More and more emphasis are being placed on political influencing instead of focusing on the technology.  Company used it’s large presence to bully individuals with disabilities especially veterans.
advice_management: Learn to refocus back on product driven innovation.  Respect for ADA and veterans with disabilities.  Similar to the respect Apple likes to emphasize with regards to their political beliefs. Example would be rewarding  employees for attentding gay parades with Apple gifts instead of simply focusing on employee merits.
